title: AB 332
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature finds that Californians are concerned about the costs of growing older, with two-thirds worried about affording long-term care and 63% as concerned about paying for long-term care as for future health care. A majority of respondents in California cannot afford more than three months of nursing home care at an average cost of $6,000 per month. About 40% of respondents cannot afford even a single month of care at that rate. Concerns about paying for long-term care are prevalent among all income levels and partisan affiliations, with 88% of Latino voters lacking long-term care insurance or unsure about coverage for supportive services like in-home care. The Legislature aims to establish a task force to explore creating a culturally competent statewide insurance program for long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will be created in the Department of Insurance to design and implement this program. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will consist of nine members, including the commissioner, Director of Health Care Services, Director of the Department of Aging, and four persons appointed by the Governor with specific expertise. Additionally, one person will be appointed by the Speaker of the Assembly from an employee representative organization. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will consist of nine members, including representatives from long-term care provider association, senior or consumer organization, long-term care workers, and long-term care insurance industry. Task force members will not receive compensation and meetings will adhere to the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act. The task force's responsibilities include specific tasks outlined in the legislation. The Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act applies to meetings of the Long Term Care Insurance Task Force, which will explore designing a statewide long-term care insurance program to expand options for individuals needing long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will explore designing a statewide program to expand options for individuals needing long-term care services, considering eligibility, benefits, financing, and interaction with Medi-Cal and other resources. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will explore options for designing a program, including eligibility, enrollment, benefits, financing, and administration. This may involve incorporating long-term care insurance into the state disability insurance program structure and allowing working adults to enroll and make voluntary premium contributions. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is considering a program for working adults to enroll and contribute premiums voluntarily. The program may include mandatory enrollment with an opt-out option, providing basic insurance benefits for those with cognitive limitations, and purchasing nonmedical services to help individuals remain in their communities. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is considering a program to help individuals with functional or cognitive limitations stay in their communities by purchasing nonmedical services. The program aims to offset costs for adults with chronic conditions and evaluate coordination with existing private health care coverage. Additionally, it will assess the demands on the long-term care workforce in California. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is evaluating the demands on the long-term care workforce in California and considering the establishment of a joint public and private system to make long-term care accessible. Recommendations will be made regarding regulatory provisions for accessing existing and future long-term care insurance programs. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will make recommendations on key regulatory provisions for public access to existing and future long-term care insurance programs. The department and participating governmental agencies will operate within their existing budgets for implementation. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will recommend options for a statewide long-term care insurance program in a report to be submitted by July 1, 2017. Participating agencies must operate within their existing budgets for this purpose. The department will produce an actuarial report of task force recommendations by July 1, 2018, for a long-term care insurance program. The commissioner may seek private funds for implementation. This section expires on January 1, 2019, unless extended by a new statute before that date.
